EXECUTIVE SUMMARY


Chemical Safety Policy

Management at The Goodyear Tire & Rubber Company, is committed to protecting the environment and the health and safety of our associates, our customers, and the communities where we operate.  The Houston Chemical Plant's Accidental Release Prevention programs prevent accidents at each stage of plant operation.  New or expanded facilities are built to current engineering standards, and hazard reviews are conducted on all chemical processes.  Process workers are trained and certified in detailed operating procedures.  Equipment is regularly inspected to standards, and is an integral part of the preventive maintenance system.

Coordinated emergency response actions between the Houston Chemical Plant and local emergency officials are planned and practiced.  By working together, the emergency response teams are prepared to take the necessary measures to protect the public if an incident occurs.

Facility Description

The Goodyear Houston Chemical Plant was built in 1943 by the U.S. government to produce synthetic rubber.  After World War II, The Goodyear Tire & Rubber Company purchased the Houston plant from the government, and has since expanded and modernized the facility.

Synthetic rubber manufactured at the facility is called "Plioflex" rubber.  To produce it, two petrochemicals, butadiene and styrene are reacted with several chemical agents in a soap and water solution.  The reaction of butadiene and styrene to produce rubber gives off heat, and the temperature of reaction is controlled by the coolant anhydrous ammonia.

Butadiene is a flammable substance that is stored under pressure in sufficient quantity to be regulated.  Anhydrous ammonia is also regulated.

Worst Case and Alternative Case Scenarios

Toxic Scenarios

The worst case toxic release scenario for the Houston plant involves a release of 25,000 pounds of anhydrous ammonia from a storage tank. This could result in a toxic plume that could extend beyond the pr

operty boundary and would have the potential to impact the public.  Corrosion monitoring of the vessel, careful control of changes to the process, and routine safety inspections make this worst case release scenario unlikely.  

The more realistic alternative release scenario for anhydrous ammonia involves the failure of a process line component resulting in the discharge of anhydrous ammonia over a one-hour period.  The impact distance when evaluated under typical weather conditions would also be expected to reach the public. 

Flammable Scenarios

The worst case flammable release scenario for the Houston plant involves a release of 1,100,000 pounds of butadiene from a storage vessel.  In the event of an unconfined vapor cloud explosion, the impact circle would reach offsite areas and have the potential to impact the public.  Corrosion monitoring of the vessel, leak detection devices, careful control of changes to the process, and routine safety inspections make this worst case release scenario unlikely.

The more realistic alternative release scenario for butadiene involves the failure of a process line resulting in minimal offsite impact in the event of an unconfined vapor cloud explosion.

Accidental Release Prevention Program

The prevention program is guided by the OSHA Process Safety Management (PSM) regulation, and applies to process operations containing the chemicals butadiene and anhydrous ammonia.  Some of the more important aspects of the accidental release prevention program are:

1. Permitting systems for hot work, confined space and vehicle entry.

2. Process hazard Analysis of processes containing butadiene and anhydrous ammonia.

3. Training and certification program.

4. Mechanical Integrity Program including:

    - Visual inspection of equipment.
    - Corrosion monitoring of vessels and piping.
    - Vibration analysis of pumps monthly.
    - Routine testing of relief valves.

5. Written operating instructions that include safe upper and lower

process limits, and emergency shutdown procedures.

6. Leak Detection and Repair program covering piping components that are monitored quarterly.


Five Year Accident History

The Goodyear Houston Chemical Plant has had no accidental releases of chemicals causing off-site environmental impacts in the last five years.

Emergency Response Program

The Goodyear Houston Chemical Plant is a member of the Channel Industrials Mutual Aid organization (CIMA), which provides emergency response assistance from neighboring plants.  Goodyear conducts training and participates in practice drills with CIMA plant members.

The Goodyear emergency response teams are trained in fire fighting, rescue, hazardous materials response, and emergency medical care.

Goodyear Houston is an active member of the Houston Local Emergency Planning Committee.

Planned Improvements

The Goodyear Houston Chemical Plant has programs and systems in place that result in continuous improvements in safety at the facility.
